audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker talking about how humans are curious about the world around them, referring to "boundaries, those frontiers of knowledge," and then speaks of "discovery" and the "simple truth" that it is good to discover and to question. The speaker then goes on to say that they are working to map the universe, and then remarks that beyond the shoreline exists a new world. He then expresses the drive to explore. The audio clip ends with a brief snippet of music.

The clip begins with a man introducing a discussion about the scientific realization that the universe has a dark side, outweighing what we can see by five times. He expresses that answering fundamental questions about dark matter drives a strong desire to learn more. He describes it as curiosity-driven, nearly obsessive, and wonders how many more years it will take to discover dark matter. At the end of his speech, there is another word that is not easily understood.

The clip begins with a male speaker with an enthusiastic tone, explaining "when we look out on the scales between the stars" we see clouds of gas and dust. He continues, stating that zooming in reveals that stars and gas clouds are distributed in "discrete objects that we call galaxies." Describing a hypothetical observation, he suggests picking "your favorite blank patch of sky," and pointing the Hubble Space Telescope at it. The clip ends with a sound effect that evokes anticipation.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing the vastness of space, stating "behind your thumbnail lies 6,000 individual galaxies," and suggesting that "all of this is an accounting error." His tone is serious and somewhat dramatic. He continues, explaining the components of simulations, where "gas is the yellow" and "blue is the dark matter."

The clip starts with a male speaker explaining how dark matter clumps begin to collapse and drag gas into a "forming halo" and giant cloud. He indicates this is the "missing ingredient" in simulations, suggesting that dark matter accelerates galaxy formation. The speaker's tone is informative and slightly academic. Following the explanation, a brief, quiet musical interlude plays, featuring a serene, ambient style.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing simulations that allow for detailed prediction of dark matter distribution, emphasizing the clumping nature and concentrating accumulations. He then reflects on how people might have studied dark matter before simulations, describing it as immensely difficult to picture the phenomenon. He draws an analogy to observing trees moving in the air, which is otherwise invisible, allowing the imagination to grasp the concept of the wind.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker drawing an analogy, "the analogy is even more apt". He explains that, similarly to how people were certain about the existence of air despite not knowing its composition, scientists now know dark matter exists through its effects on visible matter, even without knowing its exact makeup. He speaks in a steady, informative tone. The clip concludes with an indistinct sound.

The audio clip features a single male speaker explaining the concept of matter and antimatter. He describes how bringing them together leads to annihilation and energy release, specifically "gamma radiation," which he characterizes as "very, very energetic light." The speaker has an informative tone. There are no apparent background sounds or music in the provided audio clip.

The clip begins with a single male speaker discussing a theory about dark matter being its own anti-particle, the speaker has a moderately fast cadence and enthusiastic tone. He describes mapping simulated universes and identifying structures, gamma radiation, and the density of dark matter, expressing excitement about the findings with a slightly rising intonation. His tone abruptly shifts towards disappointment as he says, "no".

The audio clip begins with a male speaker stating that "at the center of the milky way is a black hole." He continues to describe that there are many dead remnant stars called "pulsars" which release a lot of gamma radiation. He finishes by saying that "we're kind of just seeing... pulsars." The speaking tone is informative and conversational.

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing the challenges of simulating self-interacting dark matter and its impact on visible matter behavior in galaxies. The speaker notes that it's unclear if self-interacting dark matter is necessary, given the uncertainty surrounding star formation and their interaction with galaxies, suggesting that there might be enough flexibility to align simulations and observations. However, the speaker mentions that as understanding of the visible sector improves, the demand for more complex dark matter models increases. He expresses a preference for a self-interacting dark matter model for its potential to offer a more interesting and complex "behavior ecology" that is currently unobservable. He attributes this inability to the challenge of seeing dark matter.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker with an informational and slightly academic tone, describing an animation involving a "slowly spiraling Milky Way" and the motion of the sun through dark matter. The speaker explains how the "wind of dark matter" impacts the Earth's movement. He mentions that this wind is faster for half the year and then slower, claiming that dark matter will have collided with atoms.  The audio ends with the speaker stating that, as a result, the atoms are knocked flying.

The audio features a single male speaker, explaining a scientific concept using a measured tone, beginning with, "we don't make... very good dark matter detections." He describes building a detector with a "sodium iodide crystal" that flashes light when dark matter collides, detected by sensitive cameras. He explains the expectation that the detector will glow "more often when we move with the direction of the sun," due to the "headwind effect". He concludes by stating, "that is the principle of sailing".

A male speaker introduces the question of where to build an experiment, noting that the detector is sensitive to anything that will collide with it, including radiation from space. He indicates that they went to Stawell, the gold mine, and are currently excavating the underground laboratory at 1024 m depth, with the detector being placed there next year. He identifies that the project is called Saber and that it will sit and wait for the collision of a ghost-like particle that will cause the crystal inside to glow. The speaker concludes by saying that if that doesn't sound like the coolest experiment, he has failed tonight.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker stating, "We have never known so little about our universe." He says that "science is not done" and highlights our lack of knowledge about dark matter and dark energy, as well as what happens on scales smaller than quarks. He mentions the recent detection of gravitational waves and the discovery of black holes and emphasizes that there is "so much we don't understand." He continues by expressing the excitement of science not being complete and suggests that aspiring scientists have vast possibilities to explore, including an "entire dark universe."
